statement.p: For each sentence below, decide whether it is an atomic statement, a molecular statement, or not a statement at all.

li.p: Eat your vegetables!
Sally ate her vegetables.
Sally ate her vegetables and got a cookie.

statement.p: Classify each of the sentences below as an atomic statement, a molecular statement, or not a statement at all. If the statement is molecular, say what kind it is (conjuction, disjunction, conditional, biconditional, negation).

li.p: Everybody can be fooled sometimes.
The Broncos will win the Super Bowl or I'll eat my hat.
If a set contains three elements, then the sum of those elements is at least 6.
Every even number is divisible by 2
Every natural number greater than 1 is either prime or composite.

statement.p: Determine whether each molecular statement below is true or false, or whether it is impossible to determine. Assume you do not know what my favorite number is (but you do know which numbers are prime).

li.p: 7 is prime and 16 is not prime
If 7 is not prime, then 7 is my favorite number.
If 16 is my favorite number, then 16+1 is my favorite number
16 is prime or 7 is prime
17 is my favorite number and 16 is not prime.
If 16 is not prime, then 16 is my favorite number.

statement.p:
Let P(x) be the predicate, 17x+1 is even.
Is P(15) true or false?
?
True
False
Neither (not a statement)
What, if anything, can you conclude about \exists x P(x) from the truth value of P(15)\text{?}
\exists x P(x) must be true.
\exists x P(x) must be false.
\exists x P(x) could be true or could be false.
What, if anything, can you conclude about \forall x P(x) from the truth value of P(15)\text{?}
\forall x P(x) must be true.
\forall x P(x) must be false.
\forall x P(x) could be true or could be false.

solution.p: P(15) is the statement 17\cdot 15 + 1 is even, which is true. Thus the statement \exists x P(x) is true (for example, 15 is such an x). However, we cannot tell anything about \forall x P(x) since we do not know the truth value of P(x) for all elements of the domain of discourse. In this case, \forall x P(x) happens to be false (since P(4) is false, for example).

statement.p:
Let P(x) be the predicate, 18x+1 is even.
Is P(15) true or false?
?
True
False
Neither (not a statement)
What, if anything, can you conclude about \exists x P(x) from the truth value of P(15)\text{?}
\exists x P(x) must be true.
\exists x P(x) must be false.
\exists x P(x) could be true or could be false.
What, if anything, can you conclude about \forall x P(x) from the truth value of P(15)\text{?}
\forall x P(x) must be true.
\forall x P(x) must be false.
\forall x P(x) could be true or could be false.

solution.p: P(15) is the statement 18\cdot 15 + 1 is even, which is false. Thus the statement \forall x P(x) is false (for example, 15 is a counterexample). However, we cannot tell anything about \exists x P(x) since we do not know the truth value of P(x) for other elements of the domain of discourse. In this case, \exists x P(x) happens to be true (since P(1) is true, for example).

statement.p: Suppose P(x,y) is some binary predicate defined on a very small domain of discourse: just the integers 1, 2, 3, and 4. For each of the 16 pairs of these numbers, P(x,y) is either true or false, according to the following table (x values are rows, y values are columns).
For example, P(1,3) is false, as indicated by the F in the first row, third column.
Use the table to decide whether the following statements are true or false.

In my safe is a sheet of paper with two shapes drawn on it in colored crayon. One is a pentagon, and the other is a triangle. Each shape is drawn in a single color. Suppose you believe me when I tell you that,
if the pentagon is purple, then the triangle is blue.
What do you therefore know about the truth value of the following statements?

li.p: The pentagon is not purple or the triangle is blue.
If the triangle is not blue, then the pentagon is not purple.
The pentagon and the triangle are both purple.
If the triangle is blue, then the pentagon is purple.
The pentagon the triangle are both blue.

solution.p: The main thing to realize is that we do not know the colors of these two shapes, but we do know that we are in one of three cases: We could have a purple pentagon and blue triangle. We could have a pentagon that was not purple but a blue triangle. Or we could have a pentagon that was not purple and a triangle that was not blue. The case in which the pentagon is purple but the triangle is not blue cannot occur, as that would make the statement false.

statement.p:
Suppose the statement,
"if the diamond is blue, then the pentagon is purple,"
is true. Assume also that the converse is false. Classify each statement below as true or false (if possible).

li.p: The pentagon is purple.
The diamond is blue.
The diamond is blue if and only if the pentagon is purple.
The diamond is blue if and only if the pentagon is not purple.

solution.p: The only way for an implication P\rightarrow Q to be true but its converse to be false is for Q to be true and P to be false. Thus we know that pentagon is purple and that diamond is not blue.

statement.p: Consider the statement, "If you will give me a cow, then I will give you magic beans." Decide whether each statement below is the converse, the contrapositive, or neither.

li.p: If I will not give you magic beans, then you will not give me a cow.
If you will give me a cow, then I will not give you magic beans.
If you will not give me a cow, then I will not give you magic beans.
If I will give you magic beans, then you will not give me a cow.
You will give me a cow and I will not give you magic beans.
If I will give you magic beans, then you will give me a cow.

solution.p: The converse is "If I will give you magic beans, then you will give me a cow." The contrapositive is "If I will not give you magic beans, then you will not give me a cow." All the other statements are neither the converse nor contrapositive.

statement.p: You have discovered an old paper on graph theory that discusses the viscosity of a graph (which for all you know, is something completely made up by the author). A theorem in the paper claims that if a graph satisfies condition (V), then the graph is viscous. Which of the following are equivalent ways of stating this claim? Which are equivalent to the converse of the claim?

li.p: Every viscous graph satisfies condition (V).
For a graph to be viscous, it is sufficient for it to satisfy condition (V).
Only viscous graphs satisfy condition (V).
A graph is viscous only if it satisfies condition (V).
For a graph to be viscous, it is necessary that it satisfies condition (V).

statement.p: Which of the following statements are equivalent to the implication, " if you win the lottery, then you will be rich, " and which are equivalent to the converse of the implication?

li.p: It is necessary for you to win the lottery to be rich.
You will win the lottery and be rich.
It is sufficient to win the lottery to be rich.
Unless you win the lottery, you won't be rich.
You will be rich if you win the lottery.

statement.p: Make a truth table for the statement (P \wedge Q) \rightarrow (P \vee Q)\text{.}

solution.p: If you think about what this statement is saying, it makes sense that it is a tautology (that it is true in every case). The complete truth table is:

statement.p: Make a truth table for the statement \neg Q \vee (Q \rightarrow P))
What can you conclude about P and Q if you knew the statement above was false?

li.p: That P and Q are both true.
That P and Q are both false.
That P is true and Q is false.
That P is false and Q is true.
None of the above.

solution.p: If this statement is false, we must be in the third row, making P false and Q true.

statement.p: Make a truth table for the statement P \wedge (\neg Q \rightarrow R)
Determine whether the statements P \rightarrow (Q \vee R) and (P \rightarrow Q) \vee (P\rightarrow R) are logically equivalent.
First, make a truth table for both of the statements. (You might want to complete the truth table on paper so you can make columns for intermediate steps; just record the final columns here.)
Are the two statements logically equivalent?

li.p: Yes, because even though the columns are not identical, there are some rows in which they are identical.
Yes, because the columns for the two statements are identical.
No, because the columns for the two statements are not identical.
No, because the statements are not always true.
Impossible to determine without more information.

solution.p: Since the two columns are identical, the statements are logically equivalent.

statement.p: Determine if the following is a valid deduction rule:
First, make a truth table for the relevant statements. (You might want to complete the truth table on paper so you can make columns for intermediate steps; just record the final columns here.)
Is the deduction rule valid?

li.p: No, because the conclusion is not always true.
Yes, because there is a row in which both premises are true.
Yes, in every row where both premises are true, the conclusion is also true.
No, because the columns for the two premises are not identical.
Impossible to determine without more information.

solution.p: There is only one row in which both premises are true (row 4). In this row, the conclusion is also true. Thus the deduction rule is valid.

statement.p: Determine if the following is a valid deduction rule:
First, make a truth table for the relevant statements. (You might want to complete the truth table on paper so you can make columns for intermediate steps; just record the final columns here.)
Is the deduction rule valid?

li.p: Yes, because there is a row in which both premises are true.
No, because the columns for the two premises are not identical.
Yes, in every row where both premises are true, the conclusion is also true.
No, because the statements are not always true.
Impossible to determine without more information.

solution.p: There is only one row in which both premises are true (row 3). In this row, the conclusion is also true, so the deduction rule is valid.

statement.p: Determine if the following is a valid deduction rule:
First, make a truth table for the relevant statements. (You might want to complete the truth table on paper so you can make columns for intermediate steps; just record the final columns here.)
Is the deduction rule valid?

li.p: No, because the columns for the two premises are not identical.
No, because there is a row in which both premises are true but the conclusion is false.
Yes, because in every row that the conclusion is true, one of the premises is true.
Yes, because there is a row in which the conclusion and both premises are true.
Impossible to determine without more information.

solution.p: In rows 3, 5 and 7 both of the premesis are true, but the conclusion is false. Thus the deduction rule is not valid.

statement.p: Determine if the following is a valid deduction rule:
First, make a truth table for the relevant statements. (You might want to complete the truth table on paper so you can make columns for intermediate steps; just record the final columns here.)
Is the deduction rule valid?

li.p: Yes, because there is a row in which both premises are true.
No, because the columns for the two premises are not identical.
No, because the premises are never both true in the same row.
Yes, in every row where both premises are true, the conclusion is also true.
Impossible to determine without more information.

solution.p: There is no row in which both premises are true (indeed, these are contradictory premises; the second is the negation of the first). Thus every row in which both premises are true (i.e., no row), the conclusion is also true. Therefore the deduction rule is valid. (This is an example of how everything follows from a contradiction.)

statement.p: Below are three statements together with a possible first line of a proof of that statement. In each case, say whether the first line is the start of a direct proof, a proof by contrapositive, or a proof by contradiction.

li.p: Statement: For every integer n, the number 7n-1 is divisible by 6.
First line: Suppose there were some integer n for which 7n-1 was not divisible by 6.
Statement: For any integer n, if n is prime, then n is solitary
First line: Let n be an integer, and assume n is prime.
Statement: If f is a differentiable function, then f is continuous.
First line: Let f be a function and assume f is not continuous.

statement.p: Let B = \{1, 3, 5, 7, 9\}\text{.} Give an example of a set A containing 3 elements that is subset of B\text{.}
What is A \cup B for the set A you gave as an example?
Give an example of two sets distinct sets A and B such that A \cup B = B\text{.}
A = ; B =

For the example you gave, is A \subseteq B\text{?}
?
yes
no
Find examples of sets A and B such that A \cup B \ne B\text{.}

For the example you gave, is A \subseteq B\text{?}
?
yes
no
Let A = \{1,2,3\} and B = \{2, 4, 6\}\text{.} Find the following sets.
f(A) = ; f(B) = ; f(A) \cup F(b) = .
Now find A \cup B and f(A \cup B)\text{.}
A \cup B = ; f(A \cup B) = .
Give an example of two distinct sets A and B such that A \subseteq B and f(A) \subseteq f(B)\text{.}
Give an example of two distinct sets A and B such that A \subseteq B but f(A) \not\subseteq f(B)\text{.}
